security_audit.summary: All 35 static findings are FALSE POSITIVES. This is a documentation-only skill containing markdown templates for code review workflows. The flagged patterns are git command examples in documentation code blocks (not executable code) and template placeholders misidentified as cryptographic code. No executable scripts, network calls, or dangerous operations exist in this skill.

content.user_title: Request thorough code reviews before merging changes
content.value_statement: Code issues found late in development are expensive to fix. This skill dispatches a code-reviewer subagent to catch problems early, before they cascade into larger issues.
actual_capabilities: Dispatches a code-reviewer subagent to analyze changes between git commits
Categorizes issues by severity: Critical, Important, and Minor
Compares implementation against documented requirements or plans
Provides specific file:line references for each identified issue
Assesses production readiness with clear verdicts
Checks code quality, architecture, testing, and security concerns
limitations: Requires git repository with commit history
Works best when requirements or plans are documented
Cannot run automated tests - only reviews code structure
Relies on subagent availability and Task tool support

use_cases.title: Pre-merge quality gate
use_cases.description: Get a thorough code review before merging feature branches to main. Catch bugs, security issues, and architecture problems early.

use_cases.title: Enforce review standards
use_cases.description: Establish consistent code review practices across your team. Every change gets categorized feedback with clear fix or proceed guidance.

use_cases.title: Fresh perspective when stuck
use_cases.description: Request a review when debugging complex issues. A second set of eyes often spots problems you have been staring past for hours.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Review Request
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my last commit. BASE_SHA is HEAD~1, HEAD_SHA is HEAD. I implemented user authentication.

prompt_templates.title: Feature Branch Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Review changes from origin/main to HEAD. I implemented the shopping cart feature per requirements in docs/cart-spec.md.

prompt_templates.title: Targeted Architecture Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Review commits a7981ec to 3df7661. Focus on database schema changes and migration strategy for the new index structure.

prompt_templates.title: Pre-Release Audit
prompt_templates.prompt: Full review of all changes in this release branch. Check for security issues, breaking changes, and production readiness. Compare against release-notes.md.

output: Strengths: Clean architecture with proper separation of concerns, comprehensive test coverage
Important: Missing progress indicators for long-running verification operations
Minor: Magic number 100 used for reporting interval should be a named constant
Assessment: Ready to proceed after adding progress feedback

output_examples.input: Check if this is ready to merge to main
output: Critical: SQL injection vulnerability in search.ts line 42 - user input passed directly to query
Important: No error handling for database connection failures
Assessment: NOT ready to merge - fix critical security issue first

best_practices: Request review after each task in subagent-driven development to catch issues before they compound
Always provide the plan or requirements reference so the reviewer can verify implementation matches spec
Fix Critical and Important issues before proceeding - only Minor issues can be deferred
anti_patterns: Skipping review because the change seems simple - simple changes can have complex consequences
Proceeding with unfixed Important issues - these accumulate and create technical debt
Ignoring valid technical feedback - push back only with concrete technical reasoning

faq.question: When should I request a code review?
faq.answer: After completing tasks, before merging to main, when stuck on a problem, before refactoring, or after fixing complex bugs.

faq.question: What git SHAs do I need to provide?
faq.answer: BASE_SHA is where changes started (previous commit or origin/main). HEAD_SHA is the current commit being reviewed.

faq.question: What if the reviewer gives wrong feedback?
faq.answer: Push back with technical reasoning. Show code or tests that prove your implementation works. Request clarification if needed.

faq.question: How are issues categorized?
faq.answer: Critical: bugs, security issues, data loss risks. Important: architecture problems, missing features. Minor: style, optimization opportunities.

faq.question: Can I skip the review for small changes?
faq.answer: Not recommended. Small changes can have large impacts. The skill helps catch issues you might overlook due to familiarity.

faq.question: What does the reviewer check?
faq.answer: Code quality, architecture, testing, requirements compliance, production readiness, security concerns, and documentation completeness.
